node.title: Shopping for Decorative Ceramics
node.alt: Ceramics “add a layer of warmth and richness” to any room, said Christine Stucker, a founder of the interior design studio Stewart-Schäfer. (The Blue Klein series ceramics start at $175 at March.)
node.description: Artisanal ceramics can be just as special as fine art — and acquiring them is usually simpler and a lot less expensive.
node.content: ["Artisanal ceramics are having more than a moment. Interest in handcrafted clay objects has been surging for years, as a new generation of artisans has taken to the kilns and fired up a white-hot design trend.", "For those seeking unusual decorative accessories that will add personality to a room, that\u2019s good news.", "\u201cThey really add a layer of warmth and richness,\u201d said Christine Stucker, a founder of Stewart-Sch\u00e4fer, an interior design studio with offices in New York and Connecticut. \u201cI just love the uniqueness of each piece.\u201d", "Ms. Stucker and her husband and business partner, James Veal, have been collecting ceramics for years, and often hunt for them as sophisticated souvenirs of their travels. \u201cIt\u2019s nice to have pieces that have a story and depth, and that mark a moment in time,\u201d Mr. Veal said. \u201cWe have more than we can even display.\u201d", "And unlike acquiring fine art, buying decorative ceramics is less involved and can be a lot less costly, he added: \u201cIt doesn\u2019t have to be expensive. They\u2019re just little things that catch our eye.\u201d", "Ribbed bowl by Christoph Radl for Bitossi Ceramiche", "Porcelain bowls with ceramic foam feet by Studio Furthermore", "Small textured ceramic tray", "Vase in matte Yves Klein-inspired blue by Bari Ziperstein", "Decorative ceramic knot"]
